parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several non-lethal methods to manage human-primate conflict have been identified.
[Statement 2]: Supporting evidence for the effectiveness of non-lethal methods to manage human-primate conflict is limited.
[Statement 3]: There is currently no evidence to determine the effectiveness of removing human food waste to deter primates.
[Statement 4]: There is currently no evidence to determine the effectiveness of installing mechanical barriers such as fences or ditches to deter primates.
[Statement 5]: There is currently no evidence to determine the effectiveness of using the scent of primate predators to deter primates.
[Statement 6]: No evidence was found regarding the control of habitat-altering mammals through exclusion or translocation to benefit primate populations.
[Statement 7]: Studies on light and sound deterrents have shown mixed results.
[Statement 8]: The use of frightening devices that emit both lights and sound was found to be ineffective at reducing crop intrusions by white-tailed deer.
[Statement 9]: The use of frightening devices that emit both lights and sound was found to be ineffective at reducing food consumption by elk and mule deer.
[Statement 10]: Red lasers were found to be ineffective at dispersing white-tailed deer.
[Statement 11]: Spotlights directed at the eyes of Asian elephants did reduce the probability of crop damage.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are some of the available and effective non-lethal actions to manage human-primate conflict?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A site comparison study in the Democratic Republic of Congo found that community control was more effective at reducing illegal bushmeat hunting, including primates, compared to the nearby national park.
[Statement 2]: A before-and-after study in Cameroon found that no incidents of gorilla poaching occurred over three years after implementation of community control and monitoring of illegal activities.
[Statement 3]: A site comparison study in Nigeria found that there were more gorillas and chimpanzees in an area managed by a community conservation organisation than in areas not managed by local communities.
[Statement 4]: Two studies in Rwanda found that gorilla populations increased after implementing regular anti-poaching patrols, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 5]: One study in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwanda, and Uganda found that gorilla populations declined after conducting regular anti-poaching patrols.
[Statement 6]: A review on gorillas in Uganda found that no gorillas were killed over a 21 month period when the number of guards carrying out anti-poaching patrols increased, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 7]: One study in Ghana found a reduction in illegal primate hunting activities following the conducting of regular anti-poaching patrols, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 8]: There is no evidence for the effects on primate populations of inspecting bushmeat markets for illegal primate species.
[Statement 9]: There is no evidence for the effects of implementing no-hunting seasons for primates.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the most effective community-led actions for reducing illegal hunting of primates?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Regular anti-poaching patrols have been associated with mixed results.
[Statement 2]: Two studies in Rwanda found that gorilla populations increased when regular anti-poaching patrols were implemented alongside other interventions.
[Statement 3]: A study in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwanda, and Uganda found that gorilla populations declined despite regular patrols.
[Statement 4]: A review in Uganda found that no gorillas were killed over a 21-month period when the number of guards carrying out patrols increased, in conjunction with other interventions.
[Statement 5]: In Ghana, illegal primate hunting activities were reduced following the implementation of regular anti-poaching patrols and other measures.
[Statement 6]: Training for anti-poaching rangers has shown positive outcomes.
[Statement 7]: In Uganda, no gorillas were killed over a 21-month period after game guards received training, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 8]: Studies in Rwanda reported increases in immature gorilla populations after staff received training as part of a broader set of interventions.
[Statement 9]: Studies in India reported increases in hoolock gibbon populations after staff received training as part of a broader set of interventions.
[Statement 10]: In Cameroon, no incidents of primate poaching were recorded over a three-year period after anti-poaching rangers were trained, in combination with other measures.
[Statement 11]: The implementation of monitoring and surveillance strategies has been beneficial.
[Statement 12]: A study in Nigeria found that more gorillas and chimpanzees were observed after the implementation of a law enforcement and monitoring system.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in India found that a population of rhesus macaques increased over 17 years following a ban on the export of the species.
[Statement 2]: Two studies in Thailand and India found that primate populations declined despite legal protection and other interventions.
[Statement 3]: A study in Malaysia found that the majority of introduced Müller's Bornean gibbons died, despite legal protection and other interventions.
[Statement 4]: In Cameroon, a site comparison of five sites found that drill populations declined in four sites but increased at one, despite legal protection.
[Statement 5]: A review in China found that primate numbers increased or no more individuals were killed after the area was legally protected.
[Statement 6]: A study in China found that Hainan gibbon numbers increased by 34% over nine years after their habitat was declared a legally protected area.
[Statement 7]: Two before-and-after studies in the Republic of Congo and Gabon found that most central chimpanzees and lowland gorillas reintroduced to legally protected areas survived over 4–5 years.
[Statement 8]: A study in Mexico found that black howler monkeys in protected areas had lower stress levels than black howler monkeys in unprotected areas.
[Statement 9]: Not all habitat protection has been successful.
[Statement 10]: One study in Kenya found that Tana River red colobus monkey and crested mangabey numbers decreased despite the area being declared legally protected.
[Statement 11]: A study in Brazil found that most reintroduced golden lion tamarins did not survive over seven years in a legally protected area.
[Statement 12]: In a Brazilian study, reintroduced golden lion tamarins did reproduce and the surviving offspring partly compensated for adult mortality.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented outcomes of using different legal protection strategies, such as protecting primate species versus protecting their habitat?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No evidence was found for the effects on primate populations of creating or preserving primate habitat on islands before dam construction.
[Statement 2]: No evidence was found for the effects on primate populations of using 'set-aside' areas of natural habitat for primate protection within mining areas.
[Statement 3]: No evidence was found for the effects on primate populations of certifying mines and marketing their products as ‘primate friendly’.
[Statement 4]: No studies were found that directly and quantitatively tested the action of creating or preserving primate habitat on islands before dam construction.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found that directly and quantitatively tested the action of using 'set-aside' areas of natural habitat for primate protection within mining areas.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that directly and quantitatively tested the action of certifying mines and marketing their products as ‘primate friendly’.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What interventions can mitigate the impacts of mining and dam construction on primate populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In logged forests, one alternative to direct supplementary feeding for improving primate food resources is using selective logging instead of clear-cutting.
[Statement 2]: One study in Sierra Leone indicated that primate densities were higher in forests with low-intensity logging compared to forests with high-intensity logging.
[Statement 3]: Another study in Madagascar observed an increase in the number of lemurs following selective logging.
[Statement 4]: A study in Uganda found that primate densities were similar in forests that had been logged at both low and high intensities.
[Statement 5]: There was no evidence found for the effects of incorporating forested corridors or buffers into logged areas on primate populations.
[Statement 6]: No evidence was found for the effects of avoiding the slashing of climbers/lianas, the trees that house climbers/lianas, hemi-epiphytic figs, and ground vegetation on primate populations.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__Within logged forests, what are some alternatives to direct supplementary feeding for improving primate food resources?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in Belize found that the number of black howler monkeys increased over a 13-year period when local communities were involved in the management of a sanctuary.
[Statement 2]: A study in Cameroon reported that incidents of gorilla poaching ceased after the implementation of a community-based monitoring scheme.
[Statement 3]: A study in Uganda found that a reintroduced chimpanzee repeatedly returned to human settlements despite the involvement of local communities in the reintroduction project.
[Statement 4]: A study in Rwanda, Uganda, and the Democratic Republic of Congo revealed that mountain gorilla numbers decreased over a 41-year period despite the implementation of an environmental education program.
[Statement 5]: There is no evidence for the effects of employing hunters in the conservation sector to reduce the hunters' impact on primate populations.
[Statement 6]: There is no evidence for the effects of reducing the size of forestry teams to include only employees.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the most beneficial community-based strategies for primate conservation?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Mountain gorilla populations in Rwanda, Uganda, and the Democratic Republic of Congo increased by 168% over 41 years when monitored continuously by veterinarians in conjunction with other interventions.
[Statement 2]: The effectiveness of veterinary screens for animals prior to reintroduction or translocation shows varied results.
[Statement 3]: A study in Brazil found that most reintroduced golden lion tamarins did not survive over seven years, despite pre-release veterinary screens and other interventions.
[Statement 4]: A study in Brazil on black lion tamarins showed that most of the animals survived for over four months after undergoing veterinary screens and other interventions.
[Statement 5]: A study in Malaysia on reintroduced Müller's Bornean gibbons indicated a 90% mortality rate despite veterinary screens and other measures.
[Statement 6]: A study in Indonesia on Bornean agile gibbons found that gibbons who underwent veterinary screens and other interventions behaved similarly to wild gibbons.
[Statement 7]: Studies in Malaysia and Indonesia on translocated orangutans showed that most of the animals survived the translocation and the initial three months afterward when the orangutans underwent veterinary screens and other interventions.
[Statement 8]: Studies in Liberia, the Republic of Congo, and Guinea on reintroduced chimpanzees showed that most of the animals survived for one to five years after undergoing veterinary screens and other interventions.
[Statement 9]: A reintroduced chimpanzee in Uganda repeatedly returned to human settlements after pre-release veterinary screens and other interventions.
[Statement 10]: Studies in Belize, French Guiana, Madagascar, Congo, and Gabon found that most reintroduced or translocated primates that underwent veterinary screens and other interventions survived for at least four months or had an increase in population size.
[Statement 11]: Studies in French Guiana, Madagascar, South Africa, and Vietnam indicated that most reintroduced or translocated primates were presumed dead post-release, despite pre-release veterinary screens and other interventions.
[Statement 12]: A study in Kenya on translocated olive baboons found that the population was still surviving 16 years after translocation with veterinary screens and other interventions.
[Statement 13]: There is no evidence on the effects that implementing a health program for local communities has on primate populations.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented outcomes of various veterinary interventions on the survival and health of wild or reintroduced primate populations?

_gemini-2-5-pro__As an alternative to providing domestic meat, what other actions can logging companies take to reduce hunting pressure from their employees, and is there evidence for their effectiveness?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several alternative actions to providing domestic meat have been suggested to reduce hunting pressure from logging company employees.
[Statement 2]: There is currently no evidence to support the effectiveness of interventions intended to reduce hunting pressure from logging company employees.
[Statement 3]: One suggested action to reduce hunting pressure is to introduce alternative food sources to replace marine, freshwater mammal, or bat meat.
[Statement 4]: Reducing the size of forestry teams to only include employees and not their family members is a suggested action to reduce hunting pressure.
[Statement 5]: Providing sustainable alternative livelihoods through the establishment of fish or domestic meat farms is a suggested action to reduce hunting pressure.
[Statement 6]: No studies have been found to evaluate the effects of the suggested alternative actions on primate, bat, or marine and freshwater mammal populations.

[Statement 1]: Creating natural habitat islands is a documented action for creating or maintaining primate habitat in agricultural land in tropical regions.
[Statement 2]: Retaining nesting trees/shelter is a documented action for creating or maintaining primate habitat in agricultural land in tropical regions.
[Statement 3]: Planting nesting trees/shelter is a documented action for creating or maintaining primate habitat in agricultural land in tropical regions.
[Statement 4]: No evidence was found to assess the effects on primate populations for the three actions of creating natural habitat islands, retaining nesting trees/shelter, and planting nesting trees/shelter.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What actions can be taken within agricultural land in tropical regions to create or maintain primate habitat?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several studies have documented both positive and negative outcomes of tourism projects for primate conservation.
[Statement 2]: In Rwanda, Uganda, and the Republic of Congo, mountain gorilla numbers increased following the initiation of tourism projects alongside other interventions.
[Statement 3]: A project in Belize saw a 138% increase in black howler monkey numbers over 13 years.
[Statement 4]: In Madagascar, one lemur species saw an increase in individuals.
[Statement 5]: A study in Rwanda found that after a tourism project was started along with other interventions, the number of immature mountain gorillas rose by 22%.
[Statement 6]: A study in Rwanda found that after a tourism project was started along with other interventions, the number of snares decreased by 30%.
[Statement 7]: In Japan, prohibiting the feeding of Japanese macaques by tourists led to a decline in aggressive interactions between the primates and humans.
[Statement 8]: Negative impacts have been observed from tourism projects for primate conservation.
[Statement 9]: In Kenya, numbers of Tana River red colobus and crested mangabeys decreased despite a tourism project.
[Statement 10]: An intensive tourism project in China for Tibetan macaques resulted in increased stress levels for the primates.
[Statement 11]: An intensive tourism project in China for Tibetan macaques resulted in infant mortality rates as high as 100% in some years.
[Statement 12]: In Madagascar, a tourism project was followed by a decline in population size for two lemur species.
[Statement 13]: In Madagascar, a tourism project was followed by a decline in body size for two lemur species.
[Statement 14]: In Madagascar, a tourism project was followed by a decline in group size for two lemur species.
[Statement 15]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of promoting mammal-related ecotourism on mammals.

key: _gemini-2-5-pro__What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of implementing tourism projects for primate conservation?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Mountain gorilla populations in Rwanda, Uganda, and the Democratic Republic of Congo that were monitored continuously by veterinarians saw a 168% increase over 41 years.
[Statement 2]: For reintroduced or translocated primates, veterinary screens conducted before release have shown varied outcomes.
[Statement 3]: In one Brazilian study, most reintroduced golden lion tamarins did not survive over seven years, despite pre-release veterinary screens and other interventions.
[Statement 4]: In a Malaysian study, 90% of reintroduced Müller's Bornean gibbons did not survive, despite pre-release veterinary screens and other interventions.
[Statement 5]: Other studies have noted high survival rates for reintroduced or translocated primates that received veterinary interventions.
[Statement 6]: Most reintroduced black lion tamarins in Brazil survived over four months with veterinary screens and other interventions.
[Statement 7]: Translocated orangutans in Malaysia and Indonesia had high survival rates of over 1-5 years with veterinary screens and other interventions.
[Statement 8]: Reintroduced chimpanzees in Liberia, the Republic of Congo, and Guinea had high survival rates of over 1-5 years with veterinary screens and other interventions.
[Statement 9]: A reintroduced chimpanzee in Uganda repeatedly returned to human settlements despite undergoing pre-release veterinary screens.
[Statement 10]: In Kenya, a translocated olive baboon population was still surviving after 16 years with the application of veterinary screens and other interventions.
[Statement 11]: Studies in French Guiana, Madagascar, South Africa, and Vietnam indicated that most reintroduced or translocated primates were presumed to have died after release, despite undergoing veterinary screens.
[Statement 12]: There is no evidence available on the effects of implementing a health program for local communities on primate populations.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in Belize found that the black howler monkey population increased by 138% over 13 years after the protection of forest along property boundaries and across cleared areas, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 2]: In Brazil, black lion tamarins and capuchins used a pole bridge to cross a road.
[Statement 3]: A study in Belize observed an increase in the black howler monkey population after the construction of pole bridges over man-made gaps.
[Statement 4]: In Madagascar, all six monitored lemur species used bridges to cross roads and pipelines.

[Statement 1]: Six out of seven studies in the USA and Canada found that some species were more abundant in selectively-logged forests when compared to control stands and other management types.
[Statement 2]: Six out of seven studies in the USA and Canada found that some species were less abundant in selectively-logged forests when compared to control stands and other management types.
[Statement 3]: One study found no consistent differences between selectively harvested stands and clearcut stands.
[Statement 4]: A replicated study from the USA indicated a lower species richness of cavity-nesting birds in snags in selectively-logged stands compared to clearcuts.
[Statement 5]: A US-based study observed that brood parasitism by brown-headed cowbirds was higher for two species in harvested stands compared to controls.
[Statement 6]: A US-based study observed that brood parasitism by brown-headed cowbirds was lower for two other species in harvested stands compared to controls.
[Statement 7]: In the context of patch retention harvesting, one before-and-after study in the USA showed that harvested areas contained more birds of more species than clearcut areas.
[Statement 8]: One before-and-after study in the USA showed that the number of birds and species in areas with patch retention harvesting was similar to unharvested areas.
[Statement 9]: Two US studies found that forest specialist species were more frequently found in patch retention plots compared to other management types.
[Statement 10]: One US study noted an increase in habitat generalists in other management types relative to patch retention areas.
[Statement 11]: There is no evidence for the effects of patch retention harvesting on primate populations.

parts.text:

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No evidence was found for the effects on primate populations of installing mechanical barriers, such as fences or ditches, to prevent primates from entering agricultural areas and raiding crops.
[Statement 2]: No evidence was found for the effectiveness of using natural hedges to prevent primates from entering agricultural areas and raiding crops.
[Statement 3]: No evidence was found for the effectiveness of using unpalatable buffer crops to prevent primates from entering agricultural areas and raiding crops.
[Statement 4]: The term 'no evidence' indicates that no studies were found that directly and quantitatively tested these actions during systematic journal and report searches.
[Statement 5]: The lack of direct and quantitative studies makes it impossible to assess the effectiveness or potential harmful impacts of using mechanical barriers, natural hedges, or unpalatable buffer crops.
